</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 style="text-align: center">Create Training and Test Datasets</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We now have several obsolete features (<code>CheckingAccount</code>, <code>CreditHistory</code> and <code>Purpose</code>), which we remove from our dataset to simplify it. We also ensure our target variable (<code>CreditRisk</code>) is our first column. This gives us dataset <code>train_test_data</code>:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [54]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="n">feature_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">CreditData</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">columns</span>

<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">removed_feature</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'CreditRisk'</span><span class="p">,</span>     <span class="c1">#Do not want target variable </span>
                                          <span class="c1">#in feature data</span>
                        <span class="s1">'CheckingAccount'</span><span class="p">,</span>
                        <span class="s1">'CreditHistory'</span><span class="p">,</span>
                        <span class="s1">'Purpose'</span><span class="p">]:</span>
    <span class="n">feature_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">feature_list</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">feature_list</span> <span class="o">!=</span> <span class="n">removed_feature</span><span class="p">]</span>
    
<span class="n">feature_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">feature_list</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">tolist</span><span class="p">()</span>

<span class="n">features</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">CreditData</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">feature_list</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="c1">#extract feature data</span>

<span class="n">target</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">CreditData</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">CreditRisk</span> <span class="c1">#extract target data</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We randomly split the dataset into a training and test dataset. Here we allocate 25% of the data to the test set. If another user also sets argument <code>random_state = 0</code>, they should get the same split in the data:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [55]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sklearn.cross_validation</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">train_test_split</span>

<span class="n">x_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">x_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_test</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">train_test_split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">features</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">target</span><span class="p">,</span> 
                                                    <span class="n">test_size</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mf">0.25</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">random_state</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 style="text-align: center">Fitting the Model</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We fit the Logistic Regression Model using the train data:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [56]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="n">reg_1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">linear_model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">LogisticRegression</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">reg_1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[56]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>LogisticRegression(C=1.0, class_weight=None, dual=False, fit_intercept=True,
          intercept_scaling=1, max_iter=100, multi_class='ovr', n_jobs=1,
          penalty='l2', random_state=None, solver='liblinear', tol=0.0001,
          verbose=0, warm_start=False)</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The model's parameters can be found as follows:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [57]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Coefficients:</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s2">"Coefficients are: {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">reg_1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">coef_</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1">#Intercept is:</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s2">"Intercept is: {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">reg_1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">intercept_</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Coefficients are: [[  3.44660518e-02   4.78464849e-05   1.15362657e+00  -5.33758260e-01
   -2.58150905e-01   5.48881221e-01  -5.83604940e-02   4.72429738e-01
   -1.08202610e+00   6.31098895e-02   5.59906892e-02   1.91112580e-01
   -1.85768826e-01]]
Intercept is: [-0.24398486]
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 style="text-align: center">Interpreting the Model</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>If the sign of the coefficient is positive, this indicates that the feature is expected to have a positive association with the probability of a bad credit risk (holding all other features fixed). If the coefficient is negative, a negative association is supported by the data.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [58]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">DataFrame</span><span class="p">({</span> <span class="s1">'Feature Names'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">feature_list</span><span class="p">,</span>
              <span class="s1">'Coefficient Values'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="n">reg_1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">coef_</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]})</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[58]:</div>
<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>
<table border="1" class="dataframe">
<thead>
<tr style="text-align: right;">
<th></th>
<th>Coefficient Values</th>
<th>Feature Names</th>
</tr>
</thead>
<tbody>
<tr>
<th>0</th>
<td>0.034466</td>
<td>Duration</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>1</th>
<td>0.000048</td>
<td>CreditAmount</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>2</th>
<td>1.153627</td>
<td>Overdrawn</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>3</th>
<td>-0.533758</td>
<td>ScaledCreditHistory</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>4</th>
<td>-0.258151</td>
<td>A43</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>5</th>
<td>0.548881</td>
<td>A46</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>6</th>
<td>-0.058360</td>
<td>A42</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>7</th>
<td>0.472430</td>
<td>A40</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>8</th>
<td>-1.082026</td>
<td>A41</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>9</th>
<td>0.063110</td>
<td>A49</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>10</th>
<td>0.055991</td>
<td>A44</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>11</th>
<td>0.191113</td>
<td>A45</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th>12</th>
<td>-0.185769</td>
<td>A48</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 style="text-align: center">Predicting with the Model</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Predictions can be found as follows (using first customer in the test dataset):</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [59]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Predicting class (-1 for Good, +1 for Bad):</span>
<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s2">"Predicted Class Label: {0}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">reg_1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_test</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]))</span>

<span class="c1">#Predicting probability:</span>
<span class="n">pr_Good</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">reg_1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict_proba</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_test</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">pr_Bad</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">reg_1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict_proba</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_test</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s2">"Predicted Probability of Good is {0}; Bad is {1}"</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">pr_Good</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">pr_Bad</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>Predicted Class Label: [1]
Predicted Probability of Good is 0.336214760976; Bad is 0.663785239024
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Note that <code>predict_proba</code> will give the probabilities for the different labels in the order of the labels' values.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 style="text-align: center">Evaluating the Model</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 style="text-align: center">Classification Accuracy</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>A simplistic approach would be to use classification accuracy:</p>
<p>$ \frac{\#Correctly Classified}{\#Test Set} $</p>
<p>This can be done using the function <code>.score()</code>:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [60]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="n">reg_1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[60]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>0.71999999999999997</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This is better than just random selection (which would lead to an accuracy of 0.5). An alternative would be a majority class prediction - we always predict the more likely value (predict always good):</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [61]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Number in majority class/Total:</span>
<span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">y_test</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nb">float</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[61]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>0.704</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Our logistic regression model is not much of an improvement over majority class prediction. However, we have used a very simple model for credit risk prediction.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h4 style="text-align: center">Precision and Recall</h4>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The provided metadata states that the cost of failing to predict a bad credit risk (False Negative) is five times the cost associated with incorrectly predicting a bad credit risk (False Positive). Hence, we are particularly concerned about the <a href="http://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.metrics.recall_score.html#sklearn.metrics.recall_score"><strong>recall</strong> metric</a>, which declines with a higher False Negative Rate:</p>
<p>$ Recall = \frac{\#TruePositive}{\#TruePositive + \#FalseNegative} $</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [62]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sklearn.metrics</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">recall_score</span>

<span class="n">recall_score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_true</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1">#True labels</span>
             <span class="n">y_pred</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">reg_1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_test</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1">#Predictions</span>
            <span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[62]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>0.35135135135135137</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Our classifier detected only 1/3 of the Bad Credit Risks in the test dataset.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>For reference, we also inculde the <a href="http://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.metrics.precision_score.html#sklearn.metrics.precision_score"><strong>precision</strong> metric</a>, which declines with a higher False Positive Rate:</p>
<p>$ Precision = \frac{\#TruePositive}{\#TruePositive + \#FalsePositive} $</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [63]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sklearn.metrics</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">precision_score</span>

<span class="n">precision_score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_true</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1">#True labels</span>
             <span class="n">y_pred</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">reg_1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_test</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1">#Predictions</span>
            <span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[63]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>0.54166666666666663</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Just over half of the bad credit risks indicated by our classifier were actually bad credit risks.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 style="text-align: center">Adjusting the Threshold</h3>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Currently, our classifier will predict a bad credit risk if the predicted probability of a bad credit risk exceeds 0.5. However, we can see above that this is resulting in a poor recall metric. One approach would be to go back and change our original model to improve the classifier. Another is to decrease the threshold from 0.5, so that there are less False Negatives (and also more False Positives). We can illustrate the impact of this with a precision-recall curve:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [64]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">matplotlib.pylab</span> <span class="kn">as</span> <span class="nn">plt</span>
<span class="o">%</span><span class="k">matplotlib</span> inline

<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sklearn.metrics</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">precision_recall_curve</span>

<span class="n">precision</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">recall</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">thresholds</span> <span class="o">=</span>  <span class="n">precision_recall_curve</span><span class="p">(</span>
                                   <span class="n">y_true</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> 
                                   <span class="n">probas_pred</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">reg_1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict_proba</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_test</span><span class="p">)[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">],</span>
                                   <span class="c1">#Note we need predicted probabilities</span>
                                 <span class="p">)</span>


<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">recall</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">precision</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'k-'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Precision-Recall Curve'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">xlabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Recall'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ylabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Precision'</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">font</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span><span class="s1">'family'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'sans-serif'</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="s1">'color'</span><span class="p">:</span>  <span class="s1">'darkblue'</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="s1">'weight'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'bold'</span><span class="p">,</span>
        <span class="s1">'size'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">16</span>
        <span class="p">}</span>

<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">index</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">thresholds</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="mi">50</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">text</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">recall</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">precision</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="mf">0.03</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">round</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">thresholds</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">fontdict</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">font</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">recall</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">precision</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="s1">'bo'</span><span class="p">)</span>
 
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">show</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>

oXVovZvfFqTF4LGeNHmsqhmtDUOY/jmF1up7VlXvq+ptVX39xzzHwFFVbQCfgJf/ddXSAjKcpEkA
eh+kz8BBkhfAKbCXZBla193+H+kc2Enypo+/7vO8An72+49zXL+0MDzWkyZ/S/RX1XWSG2C3qr4l

">
</img></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Note that the perfect classifier will have a perfect precision (equal to one), as we increase the recall. We can thus compare different classifiers using the above precision-recall, and comparing which is closest to the perfect classifier.</p>
<p>For example, the test data suggests that if we reduce the threshold to <code>0.16</code>, then over 90% of bad credit risk customers will be correctly detected. However, precision will be less than 40%:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [65]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="n">probabilities</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">reg_1</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict_proba</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_test</span><span class="p">)[:,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="n">predictions_16</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">Series</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">probabilities</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="k">lambda</span> <span class="n">x</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="mi">1</span> <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="o">></span> <span class="mf">0.16</span> <span class="k">else</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s2">"At lower threshold,"</span>

<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s2">"High Recall: "</span>

<span class="k">print</span> <span class="n">recall_score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_true</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1">#True labels</span>
             <span class="n">y_pred</span> <span class="o">=</span>  <span class="n">predictions_16</span> <span class="c1">#Predictions</span>
            <span class="p">)</span>

<span class="k">print</span> <span class="s2">"Low precision: "</span>

<span class="k">print</span> <span class="n">precision_score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_true</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="c1">#True labels</span>
             <span class="n">y_pred</span> <span class="o">=</span>  <span class="n">predictions_16</span> <span class="c1">#Predictions</span>
            <span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt"></div>
<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>At lower threshold,
High Recall: 
0.945945945946
Low precision: 
0.37037037037
</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><strong>Note that, in practice</strong>: if we were to use the above precision-recall curve to choose between classifiers and/or to select a threshold that provided the most suitable trade-off between precision and recall, we would use a <strong>validation dataset that was distinct from the test dataset</strong>. This would ensure that the model had not been optimised for the test dataset, and so the test error would be a more reliable estimate for the true error.</p>
<p>An alternative to this <strong>hold-out approach</strong> is <strong>cross-validation</strong>, which is more computationally intensive, but also means more data available for learning the model, and removes dependence on a train/validation data split.</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 style="text-align: center">Coefficient Path</h2>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>With the <a href="https://andrew47.github.io/pages/scikitlearn-regression.html">linear regression models</a>, with had a tuning parameter <code>alpha</code> used to control the degree of regularisation. We also used this parameter in the lasso regression to find those most important features that are most robust to increasing the tuning parameter.</p>
<p>With logistic regression in scikit-learn we have a similar parameter <code>C</code>, which has a similar purpose to <code>alpha</code>, except the <strong>smaller</strong> <code>C</code> is, the <strong>more</strong> regularisation.</p>
<p>As with lasso regression, we can draw a coefficient path:</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [66]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="c1">#Setting all 13 colours:</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">cycler</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">cycler</span>

<span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">gca</span><span class="p">()</span>

<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_prop_cycle</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cycler</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'color'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'lightblue'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'darkblue'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'pink'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'darkred'</span><span class="p">,</span> 
                                   <span class="s1">'lightgreen'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'darkgreen'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'gold'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'silver'</span><span class="p">,</span> 
                                   <span class="s1">'black'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'cyan'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'purple'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'orange'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'magenta'</span><span class="p">]))</span>

<span class="c1">#Setting an array of c values to examine:</span>
<span class="n">cs</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="mf">0.0001</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">0.001</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">0.01</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">0.1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">])</span>

<span class="c1">#Applying a lasso aproach to select features - hence penaly l1:</span>
<span class="n">log_reg</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">linear_model</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">LogisticRegression</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">C</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">1.0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">penalty</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'l1'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">tol</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">1e-6</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">coefs_</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[]</span>

<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">c</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">cs</span><span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="n">log_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_params</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">C</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">c</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1">#update c value</span>
    <span class="n">log_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1">#fit model</span>
    <span class="n">coefs_</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">append</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">log_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">coef_</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ravel</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">copy</span><span class="p">())</span> <span class="c1">#flattens and appends the array </span>

<span class="n">coefs_</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">coefs_</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c1">#Convert list to array</span>

<span class="c1">#Plot coefficient values against C:</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">log10</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cs</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">coefs_</span><span class="p">)</span> 

<span class="c1">#Label the graph:</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">xlabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'log(C)'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ylabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Coefficients'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Logistic Regression Path'</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1">#Create legend:</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">legend</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">labels</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">feature_list</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">bbox_to_anchor</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">0.</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.52</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="o">.</span><span class="mi">102</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">loc</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"best"</span><span class="p">,</span>
           <span class="n">ncol</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">mode</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"expand"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">borderaxespad</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">show</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Note: the above code is based on that provided in <a href="http://scikit-learn.org/stable/auto_examples/linear_model/plot_logistic_path.html#example-linear-model-plot-logistic-path-py">scikit-learn's documentation</a>.</p>
<p>Which purpose for a loan does <code>A41</code> relate to?</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [67]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="n">purpose_code_to_text</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'A41'</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[67]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>'car (used)'</pre>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The most robust feature to increasing <code>C</code> is <code>ScaledCreditHistory</code>. The above coefficient path also suggests that being overdrawn raises credit risk and borrowing to fund a used car reduces credit risk (holding everything else fixed).</p>
<p>Strangely, the poorer the credit history, the lower the probability of a bad credit risk. As we are using a very simple model, with few included features, this odd result could be due to omitted variable bias, with a poor credit history acting as a proxy for an excluded variable that improves credit risk. For example, perhaps someone with a poorer credit history might be more reluctant to borrow, unless they are sure they can pay back the money. Alternatively, the results may be being skewed by the dominance of <code>A32</code> in the dataset (over 50% of customers):</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [68]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
<div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span></span><span class="n">counts</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[]</span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">per_total</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">number</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">count</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">CreditData</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">CreditData</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ScaledCreditHistory</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="n">number</span><span class="p">])</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">count</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="nb">float</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">CreditData</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">number</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">6</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">counts</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">append</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">per_total</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">number</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="c1">#The index can be found as follows:</span>
<span class="n">index</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">arange</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1">#We can add our category labels as follows:</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">xticks</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="o">+</span><span class="mf">0.4</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">6</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="c1">#To plot the bar chart:</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">index</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">counts</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'k'</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">show</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
